His coach, Bob Bowman, designed this physical routine with Phelps.  

But that’s not all.  

He also gave Phelps a routine for his thoughts.  

He called it “Watching the Videotape.”  

There was no actual tape, of course.  

The “tape” was a visualization of the perfect race.  

Phelps would visualize every moment in exquisite detail.  

He imagined his starting position on top of the blocks.  

He pictured each stroke until he emerged victorious.  

Water dripped off his face in his visualization.  

Phelps didn’t do this mental routine occasionally.  

He did it every day before bed and upon waking.  

He practiced this for years.  

When Bob wanted to challenge him, he would shout, “Put in the videotape!”  

Phelps would push beyond his limits.  

Eventually, the routine was deeply ingrained.  

Bob barely had to whisper, “Get the videotape ready,” before a race.  

Phelps was always ready to “hit play.”  

When asked about the routine, Bowman said:  

“If you asked Michael what’s going on in his head, he’d say nothing.”  

“He’s just following the program.”  

But that’s not right.  

His habits have taken over.  

When the race arrives, he’s halfway through his plan.  

He has been victorious at every step.  

All the stretches went as planned.  

The warm-up laps were just like he visualized.  

His headphones played exactly what he expected.  

The actual race is just another step in a pattern.  

That pattern started earlier that day and included victories.  

Winning is a natural extension.  

Phelps won eight gold medals at the 2008 Beijing Olympics.  

Years later, I visited Beijing.  

I thought about how Phelps and other Olympians make feats seem effortless.  

Olympic athletes practice longer and train harder than any other athletes.  

But when they compete, they make it look easy.  

It’s more than a natural extension of their training.  

It’s a testament to the genius of the right routine.  

The Nonessentialist thinks essentials only get done when forced.  

They believe execution is a matter of raw effort alone.  

You labor to make it happen.  

You push through.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Michael Phelps' success at the Olympics exemplifies how a well-designed routine can make achieving goals feel effortless.
